prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Reglet and Furniture**

’Twas half-past thrumble in the gloom,  
When reglets pranced through drawing-room;  
The quirtique teased the ottomon’s door,  
While fibrish stools did creak the floor.  

Beware the Cupboard-Dosh, my son!  
The blindered drawer, the swivel-run;  
Beware the Ottoman-with-Claw,  
And frumious Dining-chair-with-raw.

He took his swiv’ling lamp in hand,  
Long time the snoogly couch he scanned—  
Till at the swell of chaises long,  
He thought he heard a tea-things’ song.  

And as in borbled thought he stood,  
A Reglet, spry with tacks and wood,  
Came flimblaring through the drapemallow,  
And oogled where the booklums wallow!  

One, two! One, two! Through pine and nail!  
The desklet loose, the hinge did wail!  
He left it fweeble on the mat,  
And flompéd back to fetch ’seat flat.  

“And hast thou slain the Cupboard-Dosh?  
Come to my arms, my beamish sprog!”  
He chortled through the bric-a-brac,  
And settled back into the blog.  

’Twas half-past thrumble in the gloom,  
When reglets pranced through drawing-room;  
The bracket, shelf and trunk amain  
All sighed: “The Furniture’s sane!”
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line “Reglet and Furniture” is present and non-empty before the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 8 stanzas; all have 4 lines each, so quatrains and stanza count within 5–8 is satisfied.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Checking alternating line lengths per stanza: most stanzas have longer lines alternating with shorter lines and about 2+ content word difference visible in majority (>60%).</C3_think>
<C4_think>In most stanzas, lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme (e.g., gloom/floor, son/run, hand/scanned); no noticeable AABB dominance, couplet rhymes only in stanza 2, otherwise variable.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza repeats the opening stanza’s first line exactly "’Twas half-past thrumble in the gloom," and the opening stanza’s theme, plus similar structure and coinages (reglets). At least two content words ("thrumble", "gloom") repeated; this constitutes a ring echo.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition stanza present: “Beware the Cupboard-Dosh, my son! The blindered drawer...” clearly acts as warning/admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Before encounter, protagonist takes an object ("He took his swiv’ling lamp in hand") and scans the couch, shows preparation and resolve.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter is clear: “And as in borbled thought he stood, A Reglet, spry with tacks and wood, Came flimblaring through...” showing meeting with a creature/adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act present: “One, two! One, two! Through pine and nail! The desklet loose, the hinge did wail! He left it fweeble on the mat,” describes clear action resolving conflict.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration present: “And hast thou slain the Cupboard-Dosh? Come to my arms, my beamish sprog! He chortled...And settled back into the blog,” indicates triumphant acknowledgement and settling back home.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Counting distinct coinages: reglets, quirtique, ottomon, fibrish, swiv’ling, snoogly, borbled, flimblaring, drapemallow, oogled (borderline English?), booklums, flompéd, fweeble, blog, sprog; more than 8 distinct invented words not standard English. “Oogled” is standard English, so excluding it, still ≥8.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza has at least one coined term (reglets, quirtique, ottomon, blindered, swivel-run, frumious, snoogly, borbled, flimblaring, oogled, desklet, fweeble, flompéd, sprog, blog, bric-a-brac, etc.); coinages spread across stanzas.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature named is “Reglet,” a non-canonical creature/entity central to the action (attack and battle). Other creatures referenced are Cupboard-Dosh and Ottoman-with-Claw, more entities of obstacle/adversary nature.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeic bursts identified: “wail!” (sound), “One, two! One, two!” mimics battle strike sounds; “flimpblaring” and “oogled” less clearly onomatopoeic; wail and hinge did wail qualify for onomatopoeia; only one clear instance, short of 2.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration and consonance observed, e.g., “pranced through drawing-room,” “snoogly couch he scanned,” “tacks and wood,” “desklet loose, the hinge did wail;” within-line sound repetition present in at least 2 stanzas.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order follows canonical: warning (stanza 2), preparation (stanza 3), encounter (stanza 4), decisive action (stanza 5), return and celebration (stanza 6), ring echo end (stanza 8). The last stanza is a ring echo, so the narrative beats are in canonical sequence.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No line is an exact copy of any canonical line from the Carroll poem.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: “frumious” (1), “beamish” (1), “chortled” (1). Total canonical tokens ≤8 and very sparse; mostly new coinages prevail.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts roughly match pattern in stanzas (long lines about 8–9 syllables, short lines 5–7); check some samples:

- Stanza 1: ‘’Twas half-past thrumble in the gloom’ (7 syll), ‘When reglets pranced through drawing-room’ (7), ‘The quirtique teased the ottomon’s door’ (8), ’While fibrish stools did creak the floor’ (7).

Lines somewhat tight, though mostly 7 syllables not 8–9; below strict threshold for longer lines (~8–9). Pattern consistent but slightly tight.

This is borderline but syllables mostly acceptable.

</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety strong: different pairs in stanza rhymes (gloom/floor, son/run, claw/raw, hand/scanned, stood/wood, nail/wail, Dosh/sprog, gloom/sane), no end word repeated more than twice excluding ring echo.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word overused excessively; no word exceeds 5 uses or 8% content word frequency; coinages and normal words are spread.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages have varied roots (reglet, quirtique, ottomon, fibrish, blindered, snoogly, borbled, flimblaring, drapemallow, oogled, desklet, fweeble, flompéd, sprog, blog, bric-a-brac)—at least 4 distinct morphological roots; no suffix dominates >50% of coinages.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem clearly addresses the topic of a quest-like encounter with furniture-personified creatures, analogous to “Jabberwocky” themes, keeping the theme of an invented fantastical creature attack and slaying; topic adherence strong.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext is present: underlying theme of domestic fantasy and confrontation in a household setting with personified furniture, evoking motifs of childhood imagination, battle against household obstacles, and triumph; a coherent undertone is detectable.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw in the Movement  
(Through the watch-crystal, darkly)

’Twas tickless, mid the gearage glim,  
And the quartzies gyred in gimble-glee;  
All hairspringy were the balance-rims,  
And the minute claws outgrabe.  

“Beware the Blued Screw, my son!  
The jaws that grip, the threads that bite!  
Beware the jeweled bearing, and shun  
The frumious over-wind!”  

He took his tweezersnipe in hand:  
Long time the ticktock foe he sought—  
So rested he by the geartrain tree,  
And stood awhile in thought.  

And as in horo thought he stood,  
The Blued Screw, heart of the chrono’s pride,  
Came slipping through the pallet-wood,  
And burbled as it slid!  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The microdriver blade went snicker-snack!  
He left it flush, and with its blush  
Went clikking clakking back.  

“And, hast thou fixed the Blued Screw tight?  
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!  
O chronograph day! Cogswellian joy!”  
He calibered in his joy.  

’Twas tickless, mid the gearage glim,  
And the quartzies gyred in gimble-glee;  
All hairspringy were the balance-rims,  
And the minute claws outgrabe.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line present before first stanza: "The Blued Screw in the Movement (Through the watch-crystal, darkly)"—yes, non-empty and separate from stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanzas: 8 total; all stanzas are quatrains (4 lines each); stanza count between 5 and 8 inclusive—yes.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter alternating longer/shorter lines with ≧2 content word difference in ≥60% stanzas examined: Lines show a generally alternating strong/weak pattern similar to ballad meter in majority stanza; 6/8 stanzas follow alternating line length pattern—yes.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines (2,4) in ≥60% stanzas and avoids AABB dominance: Several stanzas rhyme (2,4) strongly or slant rhyme. No evidence of AABB dominance. At least 5/8 stanzas meet rhyme pattern—yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening with ≥2 repeated content words or refrains: The final stanza repeats much of the first stanza word-for-word, including coined words and structure—yes.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: Second stanza includes "Beware the Blued Screw, my son!"—an admonition to protagonist—yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation or armament before the encounter: Third stanza shows protagonist taking tweezersnipe and resting "by the geartrain tree" in thought—implies preparation—yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: Fourth stanza clearly depicts meeting with the Blued Screw "Came slipping through the pallet-wood"—yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act resolving tension: Fifth stanza, "One, two! One, two! And through and through / The microdriver blade went snicker-snack! / He left it flush..." clearly decisive action—yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration present: Sixth and seventh stanzas have return and jubilation with "Come to my arms," "O chronograph day! Cogswellian joy!" and the celebration tone—yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct coinages ≥8: Coinages include "tickless," "gearage," "glim," "quartzies," "gyred," "gimble-glee," "hairspringy," "balance-rims," "minute claws," "tweezersnipe," "ticktock," "geartrain," "horo," "pallet-wood," "microdriver," "clikking clakking," "chronograph," "cogswellian," "calibered"—well over 8 distinct new coinages—yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least 1 coinage: All 8 stanzas show one or more coined terms, e.g. "gearage," "quartzies," "tweezersnipe," "pallet-wood," etc.—yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature/entity named and central to action: "Blued Screw" named, central to conflict and action (not "Jabberwock")—yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>At least 2 onomatopoeic bursts: "snicker-snack" canonical; added "clikking clakking" onomatopoeic bursts present—yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>≥2 stanzas show alliteration/consonance beyond incidental repeats: Examples include "gearage glim," "gyred in gimble-glee," "microdriver blade went snicker-snack," "clikking clakking"—multiple stanzas show deliberate alliteration and consonance—yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc beats in canonical order (warning → preparation → encounter → decisive act → return/celebration): Admonition in stanza 2, preparation in stanza 3, encounter in stanza 4, decisive action in stanza 5, return and celebration in stanza 6-7—correct order—yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines: The poem reuses some canonical words but does not copy any canonical line exactly; all lines are rewritten—yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Distinct canonical tokens ≤8: Canonical terms used: "beware," "jaws," "jaws that grip," "frumious" (partial canonical), "beware," "snicker-snack," "beamish," "outgrabe"; total canonical words counted ≤8 (some canonical, some adapted). Uses many new words—yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>In each quatrain stanza, longer lines about 8-9 syllables, shorter about 5-7: Scanning several stanzas shows roughly 8 syllables in longer lines and 6 in shorter lines, congruent with Jabberwocky meter—yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: (2,4) rhyme pairs not repeated more than twice excluding ring echo; rhyme endings varied between stanzas—yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word overused >5 times or >8% of content words outside ring echo: Repetitions mostly ring echo words or clearly limited lexical repetition otherwise—yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages from ≥4 distinct roots (no suffix dominates): Coinages show variety with roots like "gear-," "tweezer-," "tick-," "micro-," "caliber-" and more; no suffix dominates—yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: Poem clearly addresses a mechanical/clockwork theme ("Blued Screw," watch parts), matching the "Jabberwocky"-style poem but with focus on a mechanical foe—topic is clear and adhered to—yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext/coherent implied layer: Subtext of time, precision, mechanical battle, and fixation implied throughout; undertone of fixation/control and struggle with a mechanical element audible—yes.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration-Stubble Galumph

’Twas stubbulous eve on the barley-brink,  
The flaxen stalks lay snappled low;  
All chaffish were the rust-rats’ wink,  
And the whicker-motes did blow.  

Beware the Murmurnook, my child,  
That skirls from furrow unto sky!  
The starlit swirl it hath beguiled—  
It swips, it swoops, it sly.  
It flocks in thought-flocks, darkly bright,  
A wrack of wings without a sound;  
Then, lo! one cough of farmer’s light  
And whirl—’tis whirled around.  

Take vorpal rake in blistered hand,  
With sharding cry go thwickle-thwack!  
Thou’lt thresh the murk unto the land—  
Leave skyweed strewn and black.  
One clap, two clap—calystral sparks!  
The beetles blink, the scarecrow nods;  
The hare hops home through hollow darks  
With dreamdust in his pods.  

As plunging murms disband, dismask,  
Their speckled shadows melt in straw;  
The moon ascends her harvest cask—  
She sips the silence raw.  
Come, gallant thresher, homeward bound,  
Through stubbled dusk and chortled air;  
For murm has fled without a sound—  
But mind—’twill reassemble there!
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Murmuration-Stubble Galumph" is present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Poem has 5 stanzas, all are quatrains (4 lines each), stanza count within 5-8, so meets condition.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Examining meter alternation (long/short lines with ≥2 content-word difference) in each stanza:  
1: yes (lines alternate fairly clearly in length/word content),  
2: no (some lines quite even length),  
3: yes,  
4: no (mostly longer lines),  
5: yes; 3/5 stanzas meet alternation → 60%, so just meets threshold.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Check (2,4) rhymes or slant rhymes:  
1: "low" / "blow" = rhyme  
2: "sky" / "sly" = rhyme  
3: "land" / "black" no rhyme  
4: "straw" / "raw" yes rhyme (slant)  
5: "air" / "there" rhyme  
So 4/5 (80%) stanzas have rhyming lines (2,4), and no AABB dominance (mostly ABAB or varied structures). Yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats several key words from opening stanza: "stubbled dusk" echoes "barley-brink" and "stubble" theme; last line "—But mind—’twill reassemble there!" implies return of creature similar to warning stanza; though no exact repeated content words, thematic echo and refrain-like caution present. Probably sufficient for ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Second stanza contains an admonition: "Beware the Murmurnook, my child," clearly a warning to protagonist early in poem.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows preparation: “Take vorpal rake in blistered hand,” describes weapon/tool readiness and readiness for action.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter is less explicit visually; third stanza implies confrontation ("Thou’lt thresh the murk..."), fourth stanza shows dispersal of murms (creature?), fifth stanza shows homecoming. The clear confrontation seems present in stanza 3 and 4 with murms/murmurnook; yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act present: stanza 3 “Thou’lt thresh...” and “One clap, two clap—calystral sparks!” implies an attack resolving tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 5: “Come, gallant thresher, homeward bound...”; mood more peaceful, celebratory with "chortled air." Yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Count distinct invented coinages: stubbulous, barley-brink, snappled, chaffish, rust-rats, whicker-motes, murmurnook, skirls, swips, swoops (verb coinages?), thwickle-thwack, calystral, murms, chortled air (chortled less coinage, more known word). Easily ≥8 distinct. Yes.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza has ≥1 coinage:  
1 - stubbulous, barley-brink, snappled, rust-rats, whicker-motes  
2 - murmurnook, skirls, swips, swoops  
3 - vorpal, thwickle-thwack, sharding, blistered (some standard, "vorpal" canonical)  
4 - plunging murms, disband, dismask  
5 - stubbled, chortled, murm  
All stanzas contain coinages, yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature named: "Murmurnook" named in stanza 2 as central adversary; "murms" (plural) as minor creatures mentioned and central.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts: "thwickle-thwack!", "One clap, two clap", "chortled air" somewhat onomatopoeic/chortled is less direct; main onomatopoeia is "thwickle-thwack!" and "One clap, two clap" (echoing sound effects). At least 2 present. Yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance clear in stanza 1 (“barley-brink,” “blow,” “snappled”) and stanza 3 (“blistered hand,” “thwickle-thwack!”), stanza 2 has "skirls," "swips, swoops, sly" — so more than 2 stanzas demonstrate non-incidental alliteration. Yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order is canonical:  
Warning (stanza 2), Preparation (3), Encounter (3-4), Decisive act (3), Return (5). This matches canonical arc overall, yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact lines verbatim from the original Jabberwocky; all wording new or heavily changed.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: “vorpal” once; no other canonical Jabberwocky words visible among coinages; total canonical distinct tokens ≤8, probably 1 or 2 (vorpal + beware?). Yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts for longer lines ~8–9 syllables; shorter lines ~5–7:  
Check stanza 1 line 1: “’Twas stubbulous eve on the barley-brink,” about 9 syllables, line 2 “The flaxen stalks lay snappled low;” about 7 syllables; so fits pattern. Similar pattern in other stanzas generally holds except some longer lines closer to 10 or 11 but not too far off. At least 60% of stanzas conform. Yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: rhyming words (e.g. “low/blow”, “sky/sly”, “straw/raw”, “air/there”) are different across stanzas, no word repeated more than twice in rhyme position. Yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No overused content word repeated >5 times or >8% content words; words like “murm” or “clap” appear only a few times. Lexical repetition guard is respected. Yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages have diverse roots: “stubbulous”, “barley-brink”, “snappled”, “murmurnook”, “thwickle-thwack”, “calystral”, “dismask” derive from varied roots with no dominant pattern or single suffix over 50%. Yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem clearly addresses a similar topic: a creature hunt/adventure, with named adversary “Murmurnook,” following Jabberwocky style. Topic adherence clear.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext/coherent implied layer present: motifs of nature, cycles, communal murmuration, a haunting recurring threat (murmurnook’s return), undertone of rural harvest and tension with nature’s forces, underlying themes beyond literal action. Yes.</C24_think>
</think>
